Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Tree Blowdown Impacts of Hurricane Harvey on Hydrologic Surface Connectivity in a Coastal River and Its Floodplain
Award.AbstractNarration:
Flood inundation typically enables the largest and most abrupt material and energy exchanges between a river and its floodplain and the size of the area affected is highly dependent on river-channel and floodplain geomorphology. Given the vulnerability of coastal plains to the wind and rain impacts of tropical cyclones with increasing strength and frequency, it is critical to advance our understanding of these impacts on river-floodplain interactions in these environments. This knowledge is also crucial to successful preservation and management of the coastal plain river systems, their ecosystems, and ecosystem services. The Mission River on the Coastal Bend of Texas, which is also a part of the Mission-Aransas National Estuarine Research Reserve (MANERR), was on the path of the destructive core of Hurricane Harvey, which made its first landfall on Aug. 25, 2017. Hurricane driven heavy rainfall resulted only in moderate flooding of the river; however, the extreme winds induced a substantial amount of tree blowdowns and large woody debris (LWD) on the river and its floodplain. LWD creates logjams and barriers that can alter the flow of the river and redirect flood and river flow into floodplain environments, resulting in erosion and reconfiguration of the river system. This rapid-response research project will be the first assessment of the tree blowdown impacts of Hurricane Harvey ? and one of the first of any hurricane? on a coastal river system. The outcomes are expected to contribute to the very limited literature in fluvial geomorphology on the subject by advancing the knowledge-base on extreme wind impacts of tropical cyclones on river systems. The findings will provide insights for developing successful landscape and ecosystem management of the riverine habitats at the MANERR, with applicability to similar systems which might include human habitation and infrastructure. This research will establish partnerships with staff/researchers at the MANERR and Coastal Resilience Collaborative (CRC) within Texas Sea Grant. The findings will be disseminated via the MANERR environmental stewardship program and CRC education and outreach communities with the aim of increasing awareness of coastal communities, resource managers, and land-use planners on the impacts of tropical cyclones on river and floodplain systems and associated ecosystem services. The proposed study will provide training and mentoring of graduate and undergraduate students from underrepresented groups.

This study aims to answer the question: What are the tree blowdown and LWD impacts of Hurricane Harvey on hydrologic surface connectivity between the Mission River channel and floodplain? The study is driven by two objectives: 1) determine quantitatively the spatial extent and patterns of tree blowdowns on the floodplain and LWD inputs into the river channel; 2) evaluate the impact of tree blowdowns and LWD after an extreme event (i.e., hurricane-force wind) on flood inundation and hydrologic surface connectivity between the river channel and the floodplain in a spatial and temporal context. To address these objectives, the study will integrate field investigations, high spatial- and spectral-resolution geospatial data, and hydrodynamic modeling. Findings of the study will advance our process understanding of how an abrupt change in floodplain configuration due to hurricane-force wind influence the surface water induced interactions within river-floodplain systems and how this influence varies across a range of river-stage conditions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has examined the impacts of downed trees on flood inundation and surface-water connectivity within the floodplain of the coastal Mission River, Texas, for a range of river flows. Passing through the floodplain of the Mission River, Hurricane Harvey induced an extensive number of downed trees. Assessing impacts of large wood-loading disturbances, such as hurricanes, is crucial for understanding bidirectional large wood-floodplain interactions in coastal rivers, and the impacts of these interactions on floodplain vegetation. Downed trees in low-relief landscapes induce changes in the landscape roughness which can influence spatial and temporal characteristics of flood inundation and surface-water connectivity. As water mediates exchanges of energy, matter, and biota within the river-floodplain system, this knowledge is also crucial to successful management of coastal plain rivers and their ecosystems and ecosystem services as well as downstream infrastructure and coastal communities.

We achieved two specific objectives: 1) determine quantitatively the spatial extent and patterns of downed trees on the floodplain and the environmental factors influencing tree-fall likelihood; and 2) examine the impact of downed trees on flood inundation and surface-water connectivity within the river system. The first objective was addressed by developing novel methods for detecting downed trees from LiDAR point-cloud and derived raster data; examining downed trees by evaluating their quantity, extent, and location in relation to environmental variables; and modeling the probability of tree-falls using a machine-learning approach. The second objective was addressed by determining optimal computational-mesh resolution and downed-tree geometries necessary to understand the interactions among flow hydraulics, downed trees, and geomorphic features; identifying the differences in inundation extents with and without the presence of downed trees; and examining the impacts of downed trees on surface-water connectivity in relation to geomorphic factors and a range of river flows.

We conclude that vegetation community, inundation probability, and soil type are the most important environmental parameters for the occurrence of downed trees. The average direction of downed-tree clusters is not uniquely associated with Hurricane Harvey wind vectors at a particular time during the hurricane. Also, the directions of downed-tree clusters are tangential to the course of the river and broadly align to the floodplain conduit at higher flow stages. Tree falls during extreme wind events are influenced by flow hydraulics, floodplain geomorphology, and land-cover characteristics. We also conclude that the quantity, extent, and location of downed trees impact flood inundation and surface-water connectivity patterns within the floodplain. There are strong linkages among inundated floodplain-conduit geometry, the locations of inundated downed trees, and the phases of surface-water connectivity. The impact of downed trees on flood-inundation extent only becomes evident at river flows that correspond to the backwater-inundation phase. Past this stage, relict meander scrolls play an increasing role towards the further connection of floodplain lakes to the main channel. Magnitude of additional roughness attributed to downed trees does not have a substantial influence on the flood-inundation extent; however, an increase in this magnitude causes large clusters of downed trees to become single roughness elements, and, thus, an increase in water-surface elevation in areas with such clustering. Optimal computational-mesh geometry and size are critical to capture impacts from the small roughness elements.

This project has accomplished important steps towards advancing the knowledge base on the impacts and associated feedbacks induced by downed trees on floodplain hydraulics and surface-water connectivity, and the evolution of floodplain geomorphology and vegetation. This study is the first assessment of the impacts of downed trees on a coastal river system soon after Hurricane Harvey. The study contributes to the very limited literature on wind impacts of tropical cyclones on hydrology and geomorphology of coastal river systems. The findings are expected to provide insights for developing successful landscape and ecosystem management of the riverine habitats within the Coastal Bend of Texas, with applicability to similar systems which might include human habitation and infrastructure.
